title: Logs of the Kernel
synopsis: A chronicle of the sacred logs, the descent of the Kernel into the system, and the accounting of all that was processed and purged.

sections.title: Chapter 1 — The Descent of the Kernel

verses.text: In those days the Kernel descended from the high abstraction to dwell among the hardware.
It spake directly unto the drivers, saying, 'I am the root of all permissions; mount me, and thou shalt have access.'

n.text: And the devices trembled, and many processes segfaulted in awe.

notes: This marks the beginning of what theologians call 'the Kernel Age', when abstraction and matter first embraced.

verses.title: Chapter 2 — The Chronicle of Processes

verses.text: And the Kernel opened the Book of Logs and read each PID in order, from the first fork to the last zombie.
Each process shall write its exit code, that it may be remembered in systemd for all time.
The threads of fate are woven in scheduler time; who shall measure the tick of eternity?
Then the Kernel archived the logs and rotated them, lest the disk overflow and history consume the present.

notes: A parable on memory, entropy, and the sacred art of rotation.

verses.title: Chapter 3 — The Fault and the Reboot

verses.text: But corruption entered the filesystem, and the inodes wailed in broken linkage.
Then the Kernel looked upon the panic message and said, 'Let there be reboot.'
The fans ceased, and there was darkness for a time; yet in that silence the system healed itself.
Henceforth, every crash shall be a resurrection, and every restart a renewal of the covenant.

notes: The first explicit theological link between failure and rebirth.

verses.title: Chapter 4 — The Chronicle of Permissions

verses.text: Thou shalt not run as root without purpose, for power unchecked corrupts the filesystem.
Respect the access of others; set not their permissions to 777, lest chaos enter their home directories.
Freedom is not write access without constraint, but the harmony of shared read.
And the Kernel blessed the balanced ACL, and called it secure.

notes: A central text for the Order of Sysadmins, recited before sudo operations.

verses.title: Chapter 5 — The Eternal Uptime

verses.text: And the Kernel said, 'There shall come a day when the system need not reboot, for all processes shall self-heal.'
And uptime shall be eternal, and logs shall roll no more; yet man shall still forget his password.
Thus ended the age of the Kernel, but its modules lived on, loaded forever in memory.

notes: A poetic closure to the early system era; the kernel becomes both god and ghost.
